title: 114_s1109
content: The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" requires federal agencies to provide information on settlement agreements. The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" mandates federal agencies to disclose details of covered settlement agreements related to alleged violations of federal laws. The "Truth in Settlements Act of 2015" requires federal agencies to disclose settlement agreements related to alleged violations of federal laws that involve payments of at least $1,000,000 by non-Federal persons or relate to an Executive agency's rule-making process. The term 'entity within the Federal Government' includes officers or employees acting in an official capacity. The term 'non-Federal person' refers to individuals outside the Federal Government. The term 'entity within the Federal Government' includes officers or employees acting in an official capacity. The term 'non-Federal person' refers to individuals outside the Federal Government. The head of each Executive agency must make information available online in a searchable format. The head of each Executive agency is required to publicly post a list of covered settlement agreements online in a searchable format, including the date of each agreement. The Executive agency must publicly list covered settlement agreements online, including dates, parties involved, and claims settled. The Executive agency must publicly list covered settlement agreements online, including dates, parties involved, claims settled, and details of the settlement amounts. The settlement agreement specifies the total amount each party is obligated to pay. The settling party is obligated to pay the amount specified in the covered settlement agreement as a civil or criminal penalty or fine, and any amount specified as not deductible for Internal Revenue purposes. The covered settlement agreement specifies amounts that are not deductible for Internal Revenue purposes and where the collected amounts will be deposited. The covered settlement agreement specifies non-deductible amounts and where they will be deposited, including potential use for Federal Government programs. Disclosure of agreement details may be required. The Executive agency must disclose covered settlement agreements, except for information subject to confidentiality provisions. The head of each Executive agency must ensure that information on covered settlement agreements is publicly available for at least 5 years, and copies of the agreements are also made public. The head of each Executive agency must ensure that information on covered settlement agreements is publicly available for at least 5 years, and copies of the agreements are also made public for specified periods. The head of an Executive agency must issue a public statement if a confidentiality provision or sealing of a covered settlement agreement is deemed necessary to protect the public interest of the United States. The head of an Executive agency must issue a public statement explaining why a confidentiality provision or sealing of a covered settlement agreement is necessary to protect the public interest of the United States, outlining the interests confidentiality protects and why they outweigh the public's interest in knowing about the government's conduct and use of resources. The head of an Executive agency must justify the need for confidentiality in a settlement agreement, explaining why it outweighs the public's interest in knowing about government conduct and resource expenditure. Written public statements must specify the amount to be paid by a non-Federal person under the agreement. The covered settlement agreement must specify if any portion of the amount to be paid by a non-Federal person is a civil or criminal penalty for a violation of Federal law or not deductible for tax purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The covered settlement agreement must specify if any portion of the amount to be paid by a non-Federal person is a civil or criminal penalty for a violation of Federal law or not deductible for tax purposes under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Additionally, it should include details on any actions the non-Federal person will take instead of making payments to the government. The covered settlement agreement must detail the actions a non-Federal person will take in place of payment to the government and any payments to other non-Federal persons. Disclosure of information is required unless subject to confidentiality. The covered settlement agreement requires disclosure of information unless subject to confidentiality provisions. Executive agencies must report on covered settlement agreements annually. The head of an Executive agency must report to Congress on covered settlement agreements, including the number of agreements and any required terms or conditions. The Executive agency must report to Congress on covered settlement agreements, including the number of agreements, terms, conditions, and total payments to non-Federal persons. The Executive agency must report to Congress on covered settlement agreements, including the total amount of attorney fees, costs, and expenses paid to non-Federal persons, and the number of agreements involving regulatory action or changes. The Executive agency must report to Congress on settlement agreements, including regulatory actions, and make the report publicly available on their website. The Executive agency must report to Congress on settlement agreements, including regulatory actions, and make the report publicly available in a searchable format on their website. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress on how Executive agencies determine the confidentiality of settlement agreements, with recommendations for increasing transparency while protecting legitimate interests. The Senate passed the bill on September 21, 2015, as attested by Secretary JULIE E. ADAMS.
